name: Distillery
description: A large but partially abandoned vodka distillery on the outskirts of Cassandra. Although the facility appears sizable, much of it is unused, giving the place a cold, hollow, and economically declining atmosphere.

snapshot.name: William Distillery
snapshot.description: The distillery feels quiet and desolate. Large sections of the facility stand empty, machinery idle and coated with dust. The air smells faintly of alcohol and cold metal. Shortly after the investigators arrive, they encounter the distillery owner and directly witness his sudden death.

characters.name: Abel William
characters.notes: A middle-aged man who inherited the distillery after his father’s death. He struggled to manage the business and believed economic decline was the cause of its failure.

clues.clueText: Large portions of the distillery are completely unused, suggesting long-term decline rather than a sudden shutdown.
reveals: The distillery has been failing for a long time.

clues.clueText: The investigators personally witness the death of the distillery owner upon arrival.
reveals: This death may be connected to the broader events unfolding in Cassandra.

conditions.description: Cold and drafty due to the vast empty interior.
A lingering scent of vodka and industrial alcohol.

events: The distillery owner (Abel William) dies in front of the investigators. His body begins to convulse, and a black spider crawls out from his neck, leaving a circular hole. The spider immediately disappears into the darkness. William's neck shows a circular blood hole, and blood spreads through his beard. He is already dead.

Investigators should leave immediately—no one will discover they were here. The next day, William's death will be reported in the newspaper, stating he was killed by a sharp object to the neck. His body will be found in the wine cellar, but only the investigators know the actual circumstances.

exits.description: A wide industrial gate leading out of the distillery grounds.

snapshot.keeperNotes: The death at the distillery is meant to be witnessed, not prevented. Emphasize the emptiness and decline of the location to reinforce the sense of inevitability.

connections.description: The aftermath of the distillery owner’s death may involve medical or official handling of the body.
